body:
In my understanding, `@BeforeEach` and `@AfterEach` (and equivalent extensions) mean **@BeforeEachTestMethodInvocation** and **@AfterEachTestMethodInvocation**.

In your case, only one method defines DynamicTests, so, only one invocation of this test method is done, along with one invocation of `@BeforeEach` method.
The behavior is intended but needs better documentation: The methods/callbacks are only executed for test factory methods, not for the dynamic tests they produce.
See related discussions in #374 and #386 for further inspiration.

issue.title: Reword to clarify how callbacks affect dynamic tests.

body: Hi, I've created a pull request that I hope clarifies the callback lifecycle for dynamic tests.

Thanks @hglasgow -- but please run `gradle spotlessApply` and then squash your changes and force push.

With #813 on the horizon we need to update and clarify the "dynamic tests" documentation, again. :)
Hmmm. The CI checks are failing. _"Run 'gradlew spotlessApply' to fix these violations."_ But this task has no effect on the file when I run it locally. Eclipse Neon; Windows 10.

> _"Run 'gradlew spotlessApply' to fix these violations."_ But this task has no effect on the file when I run it locally. Eclipse Neon; Windows 10.

That sounds a bit odd.

What happens if you run `gradlew spotlessApply` from the command line?

Also, it appears that you simply have trailing spaces at the end of several of those lines. So manually deleting all trailing spaces might resolve the problem for you.
Thanks, removing the trailing spaces has fixed the CI builds.

@hglasgow, glad that sorted it out for you!

Let's see what @avandeursen has to say about your proposal.

rename.from: Dynamic Tests in class with BeforeEach methods
